trial_identification.studytitle: Psychological Adjustment to Breast Cancer Diagnosis and Treatment: Evaluating an Interactive Self-Help Workbook.
trial_identification.scientifictitle: A randomised controlled trial comparing a self-help workbook with an information-control in improving coping, distress and quality of life in women recently diagnosed with breast cancer.

interventions.interventions: The self-help workbook was entitled "Finding Your Way". This intervention consisted of several components, including: education about common psychosocial issues, relaxation and meditation (relaxation/meditation CD included), suggestions, cognitive behaviour therapy worksheets, survivor quotes and stories, and therapeutic writing. The level of utilisation was up to participants, but was monitred via structured feedback phone calls at 1 and 2 months, and via self-report at follow-up assessments. The total duration of the study was 6 months.
interventions.comparator: Information-control: this was also entitled "Finding Your Way" and contained identical information to the workbook, but provided no suggestions, worksheets or relaxation/meditation CD. Usage of the control condition was monitored via self-report at the 3 and 6-month follow-up assessments. The overall duration of the study was 6 months.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Distress: Depression scores as measured by Depression Anxiety stress Scale
primaryOutcome.timepoint: baseline, then 3-month and 6-months after intervention received

primaryOutcome.outcome: Distress: Anxiety scores as measured by Depression Anxiety Stress Scale
primaryOutcome.timepoint: baseline, then 3-month and 6-months after intervention received

primaryOutcome.outcome: Distress: Truamatic stress as measured by the total scale score of the Posttraumatic Stress Scale-Self Report
primaryOutcome.timepoint: baseline, then 3-month and 6-months after intervention received

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Quality of life (QOL): Global QOL, measured by EORTC QLQ-C30
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: baseline, then 3-month and 6-months after intervention received

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Quality of life: Body Image, measured by EORTC BR-23.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: baseline, then 3-month and 6-months after intervention received

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Maladaptive coping: helplessness/hopelessness - measured by the mini-Mental Adjustment to Cancer Scale
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: baseline, then 3-month and 6-months after intervention received

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Maladaptive coping: anxious preoccupation - measured by the mini-Mental Adjustment to Cancer Scale
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: baseline, then 3-month and 6-months after intervention received

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Maladaptive coping: cognitive avoidance - measured by the mini-Mental Adjustment to Cancer Scale
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: baseline, then 3-month and 6-months after intervention received

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Stage 0 to II breast cancer, diagnosed in the previous month, English speaking, aged 18 years or over
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: pre-existing neurological condition (e.g., dementia) Insufficient english to complete questionnaires/read workbook

trial_design.concealment: Women were informed of the study by a breast care nurse, and those interested were subsequently contacted by the researcher. Allocation was implemented through the use of numbered containers and the sequence was concealed until interventions were assigned.
trial_design.sequence: Block randomisation was employed, and the sequence was generated via computer.

secondarysponsor.sponsorname: Flinders Medical Centre Foundation Lyn Wrigley Award

ethicsAndSummary.summary: Despite the impact of breast cancer on distress and quality of life (QOL), most Australian women refuse to participate in group psychological treatments. Therefore innovative interventions are required. The current study aimed to evaluate whether an interactive self-help workbook (WB) has greater improvements than an information booklet in depression, anxiety, traumatic stress, QOL and coping for women recently diagnosed with breast cancer.
ethicsAndSummary.publication: 1. The International Psycho-Oncology Society 10th World Congress of Psycho-Oncology, Madrid, Spain, 9-13 June 2008 2. The 31st Australian Association for Cognitive Behaviour Therapy National Conference, Adelaide, Australia, September 17-21 2008
